introduction.p:
The learning objectives for this chapter are:
To understand and be able estimate with confidence.
To understand and be able to find confidence intervals for a population mean.

section.title: Confidence Intervals for Population Means

example.p:
Anyone who has ever seen the move Jaws knows that great white sharks are really big and really hungry. They are at the top of the food chainwell almost, orcas (AKA killer whales) have been known to prey on great whites. Your friend Brian has seen Jaws 25 times as well as all of the sequels. He claims that the average length of a great white is 20 feet. As evidence, he tells you that a 37 ft shark was trapped in a herring weir in New Brunswick, Canada, in the 1930s. Table gives the lengths in feet of 44 great whites. Two questions:
Is your friend Brian correct?
What is the average length of a great white?

table.caption: Lengths of great white sharks (in feet)

statement.p: Is there significant evidence that your friend Brain is correct? Or is he just going off the deep end as usual? Assume that the population standard deviation is known and is \sigma = 2.55 feet.Actually, we do not know \sigma, and it would be better to use a t-test.

section.p: We would like to use statistics to obrain a realistic estimate of the average length of a great white shark from our sample of 44 sharks. We will do this by calculating a confidence interval for the population mean.

Suppose that we choose a simple random sample of size n from a population where we know the standard deviation \sigma and we wish to estimate the mean \mu. A level C confidence interval for \mu is \overline{x} \pm z^* \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}. The value of z^* is given in Table.

example.p:
Our goal is the calculate a 95 confidence interval for the length of a great white shark from the data in Table. We will assume that the population standard deviation is known and is \sigma = 2.55 feet.
Calculate the mean. \overline{x} = 15.59.
From Table determine z^* = 1.960.
A 95 confidence interval is given by \overline{x} \pm z^* \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} = 15.59 \pm 1.960 \frac{2.55}{\sqrt{44}} = 15.59 \pm 0.75.

sage.input: sharks <- c(18.7, 16.4, 13.2, 19.2, 12.3, 16.7, 15.8, 16.2, 18.6, 17.8, 14.3, 22.8, 16.4, 16.2, 16.6, 16.8, 15.7, 12.6, 9.4, 13.6, 18.3, 17.8, 18.2, 13.2, 14.6, 13.8, 13.2, 15.7, 15.8, 12.2, 13.6, 19.7, 14.9, 15.2, 15.3, 18.7, 17.6, 14.7, 16.1, 13.2, 12.1, 12.4, 13.5, 16.8) xbar = mean(sharks) #sample mean sigma = 2.55 # population standard deviation n = length(sharks) # sample size sem = sigma/sqrt(n) # standard error of the mean E = qnorm(.975)*sem # margin of error, 95% confidence level implies 97.5% of the normal distribution in the upper tail xbar + c(-E, E) # confidence interval

statement.p: Table the IQ test scores for 31 seventh-grade girls in a Midwest school district. If we treat the 31 students as a simple random sample of all seventh-grade girls in the district, what is a 90 confidence interval for the mean IQ score of all seventh-grade girls in the district? Assume that the population standard deviation is \sigma = 15.

section.title: Confidence Intervals for Population Proportions
section.p: Confidence intervals for proportions work much the same way as confidence intervals for means except that we replace the standard deviation with the standard error of \hat{p}, \text{SE} = \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1 - \hat{p})}{n}} Thus, our confidence interval is given by \text{estimate} \pm \text{margin of error} = \text{estimate} \pm z^*\text{SE}.

example.p: Bruce Long and Susan Jordan are candidates for a tightly fought race for a seat in Congress. You are planning a sample survey to find out how many voters plan to cast their ballot for Ms. Long. You will contact a simple random sample of likely voters in the 4th Congressional District. You want to estimate p, the proportion of voters who will cast their ballot for Ms. Long with a 95 confidence interval. In a sample of 500 voters, 270 said that they planned to vote for Ms. Long. Thus, our confidence interval is given by \hat{p} \pm z^* \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1 - \hat{p})}{n}} = 0.54 \pm 1.960 \cdot 0.0223 = 0.54 \pm 0.0437.

paragraphs.title: Sample size for a desired margin of error
paragraphs.p: The level C confidence interval for a population proportion p will have a margin of error approximately equal to a specified value m when the sample size is n = \left( \frac{z^*}{m} \right)^2 p^*(1- p^*), where p^* is the guessed value for the sample proportion. The margin of error will be less than or equal to m if you guess p^* = 0.5.

statement.p: How many voters would need to be polled in order to have an error of no larger than 3 or 0.03?

hint.p: Assume p^* = 0.5. Why can you make this assumption?
